posts.name: Ziv Itzhak
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone, We’re looking forward to upgrade our bumpers and use foam instead of pool noodles for the wood coating. Where do you recommend to buy the foam from? (That ships internationally) And what methods are recommended to lay the numbers?

Any advice would be great. Thank you

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Surely someone in Israel sells foam floor tiles like these , right?  Harbor Freight is “the cheap stuff” here in the US, these tiles are nothing fancy.  We used Opticutter to figure out how many of what we needed, and that spat out two layouts we needed to cut multiple times.

Use cheap carpet tape to hold together a stack of them (we found an asterisk pattern works well), then run them through a bandsaw to make a billet of the right size (or usually, half-length of your bumper).  We ran ours and 10591’s awful fast.

One thing to know: if you’re used to getting rolls of material from AndyMark or anyone else representing they’ll cover a whole robot’s worth, high chance it won’t cover a whole set like this.  We got caught out when finishing ours, and we were saved by the FSC Bumper Elves who had extra material.

As for numbers, heat transfer vinyl seems to be the sauce. Maybe paint if you have time or are desperate.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: I have no advice on getting foam internationally.  Number materials are very dependent on your base fabric. Pourous fabrics  like cordura respond very well to iron on vinyl and fabric paint. Relatively impervious fabrics like most sail or pack cloth are going to do better with a high strength pressure sensitive adhesive. Embroidered or sew on numbers will stick to any but they are harder to do well, and can weaken the underlying fabric in some cases.

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked: International shipping is tricky.  I got nuthin’.  But for folks here in the US I’d suggest https://www.foambymail.com Nice to work with.  We went with cross linked poly.  And on the numbers application question, having nice flat, minimally compressible surfaces means you can apply the numbers after the bumpers are done.  With the irregular surfaces of pool noodles that was somewhere between Difficult and Bad Idea.
posts.display_username: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: Be warned that floor tiles were added because we (the bumper working group) wanted to allow FTC floor mats and most of those don’t actually list the material. (EVA) The floor tile rule ended up extremely broad, and includes many foams we didn’t have in mind and you will be able to find legal but not suitable foam floor tiles.

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked:
we made a Build Log post about our bumper upgrades, you could probably find the same foam from a local supplier

FRC 9496 LYNK | 2025 Build Log FRC Open Alliance

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Be warned that floor tiles were added because we (the bumper working group) wanted to allow FTC floor mats and most of those don’t actually list the material. (EVA) The floor tile rule ended up extremely broad, and includes many foams we didn’t have in mind and you will be able to find legal but not suitable foam floor tiles.

Fair.  We found the HF ones (which list they’re EVA foam, without much else detail) to be significantly stiffer than the pool noodles we’ve found in recent years, which contributed to our inability to intake floor algae but by golly they took all the abuse we could throw at them.

10591 made playoffs at all three events this year in defender roles, including Round 5 at SCCMP, and they never had a bumper concern despite at least a few hard whacks right into the truss.  And while we made our bumpers out of nice plywood, their wood backing was OSB that looked awful flimsy (but which I wasn’t prepared to push on because we had other fish to fry to ensure they were finished and could play).

Teams should absolutely be choosy, but comparable floor tiles should be available locally in most developed parts of the world.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: Yeah, as far as my research could get me, typical foam floor tiles of the FTC type are about 6lb/ft3 but based on my samples, 3-4lb/Ft3 is probably a nicer stiffness.

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked:
I have been told by trusted sources (but have not tried this myself) that IF you use floor tiles, you can cover your bumpers with fabric and then iron your iron-on vinyl numbers.

Yes, directly over the foam tiles.   I have been told the tiles do not melt.

YMMV, of course I recommend you test this first.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Coach 3128  - Mech, Laser, Bumpers, Fix all the Things, Travel

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked:
My personal favorite is cross-linked Polyethylene foam.  3128 purchased foam from:

2# cross-linked Slab Foam from The Foam Factory 1” thick slabs (white) 3# cross-linked Slab Foam from The Foam Factory ½” thick slabs (grey)

image 652×763 47.4 KB

image 652×763 47.4 KB

image 652×763 47.4 KB

An AI google search yielded this:  " In Israel, polyethylene foam is primarily produced and supplied by Palziv Group and its subsidiary, Foamotive . Palziv specializes in cross-linked polyethylene (XLPE) foam , offering it in rolls, blocks, and custom-shaped products. Foamotive focuses on foam parts for the automotive industry, supplying OEMs and Tier 1 companies with various foam components like seals and gaskets."

If you can get any info from Palziv about their XLPE  (cross-linked polyethylene) foam, and get it (locally) in Israel - problem solved?

Their datasheets list: PALZIV Kibbutz Ein Hanatziv 10805 Israel. Tel: 972-4-6062999 Fax: 972-4-6062958 www.palziv.com Email: contact@palziv.com

PE foam between 1.5 - 3 lbs/cubic foot translates to 24 - 48 kg/cubic meter

from their website and datasheets: “Palfoam is a closed cell cross-linked polyethylene foam block.” “Galfoam is closed cell cross-linked polyethylene foam sheet, produced in extrusion process.”

I looked at a couple datasheets (not all) and PA30, PA40, PM30, PA33FRZ, GA29FBZ, GA33FIZ are within the density limits and legal for bumpers.  I’m sure there are others?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Coach 3128  - Mech, Laser, Bumpers, Fix all the Things, Travel

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked:
Bumper numbers.  What a loaded topic.

Bumper numbers (what you make them out of, how you apply them) REALLY depend on:

your bumper fabric

bumper foam

IF you stick to a coarse, durable fabric such as cordura (or other dense woven nylon fabric), and foam is pool noodles/ PE foam/EVA foam, your choices are:

iron-on vinyl numbers, cut and ironed to the fabric before it is attached to the bumpers

fabric numbers, cut and sewn before attaching to bumpers

stencil/paint numbers AFTER fabric is attached to bumpers

Best paint that actually survives combat:

speedball screenprinting ink (credit to Katherine of FRC 2960, she swears by this, I have not tried it)

Rustoleum vinyl spray paint (credit to JJ Sessa of FRC 4414) image 866×730 61.7 KB image 308×821 80.9 KB Note about Rustoleum:

image 866×730 61.7 KB

image 866×730 61.7 KB

image 308×821 80.9 KB

image 308×821 80.9 KB

takes multiple coats (like 6 or more)  to get an opaque white

Suggest you use a thin stencil, stuck to bumpers with a spray fabric glue, mask off the rest of the bumpers.

Each coat dries in 10 minutes or less at 100% humidity (as in, tried in my garage in a thunderstorm).

If you choose any other fabric… test it first.  Iron on some vinyl, spray paint, whatever.

There are fabrics that NOTHING will stick to (except the algae ball of 2025).  Silicone impregnated nylon parachute fabric, for instance.
